The Ocean Is Starting to Lose Its Memory, Scientists Warn
-- Peter Dockrill
The oceans that surround us are transforming. As our climate changes, the world's waters are shifting too, with abnormalities evident not only in the ocean's temperature, but also its structure, currents, and even its color.

As these changes manifest, the usually stable environment of the ocean is becoming more unpredictable and erratic, and in some ways the phenomenon is akin to the ocean losing its memory, scientists suggest.

"Ocean memory, the persistence of ocean conditions, is a major source of predictability in the climate system beyond weather time scales," researchers explain in a new paper led by first author and climate researcher Hui Shi from the Farallon Institute in Petaluma, California.

"We show that ocean memory, as measured by the year-to-year persistence of sea surface temperature anomalies, is projected to steadily decline in the coming decades over much of the globe."

This makes me so mad to watch. Why did we collectively decide to use plastic, which will outlive us all sevenfold, for things we throw away either immediately or after a temporary period of time? We should’ve banned the use of plastic for most disposable products long ago and resorted to other materials, like paper, glass, wood, stainless steel, etc.

As if the threat weren’t big enough, we also have microplastics to deal with, which has just gotten worse since this video was made; recently, scientists found, for the first time, microplastics in human blood. Human blood! This godforsaken invisible, indigestible stuff that’ll likely outlive Earth itself is in our blood streams!

comment_text: The real issue with plastic is not the plastic it's self, but the lack of good recycling facilities. I don't want to oil industry to go bankrupt. Recycling is the answer. I think we should teach children from a young age how to recycle properly and all hospitals, schools and businesses and care homes should be required to recycle by law. Metals are elements and can be used over and over again, we just need to use the technology available, because we already have the tech to solve climate change. This video is awesome! I'd like to point out, though, that in addition to avoiding directly consuming plastic products, I think we all ought to consider more critically the plastic pollution inherent in the production of non-plastic products we consume.

Refusing plastic straws is great, but a 2018 study (1) showed that plastic straws only compose about .03% of the plastic in the GPGP. On the contrary, discarded fishing equipment accounts for 46% of that plastic. That means avoiding fish is 3 orders of magnitude more effective at preventing plastic pollution than avoiding plastic straws is. That is an incredible figure.

And even without all the plastic pollution, the fishing industry is incredibly unsustainable. Plastic kills millions of marine animals in a year (2), but millions of marine animal are killed for food each minute (3). That has a far more devastating impact on ecosystems than plastic does. Fish populations are declining at an alarming rate (4), and considering the ocean's role as one of our planet's best carbon sinks, that's a terrifying prospect.

If you want to engender positive change, cutting out fish, or better yet adopting a plant based diet, is the most effective method of making an individual sustainable impact.

Recycling Reimbursement Incentive Program (RRIP). One part of the plastic solution would be adding a Financial incentive to recycle. Below are the steps: Charging/adding a recycling fee/tax of .50 per bottle at the point of purchase. Then when a collector goes to a processing plant they receive that .50 from the recycling plant. Then the RRIP would reimburse that .50 to the processing plant. Then that plastic is converted into fuel for heating, cars ect... The plastic recycling program would be the same as other recycling programs. For example, if a person collects 60 bottles they would receive $30 at the location of the processing plant. Then the RRIP  (Recycling Reimbursement Incentive Program) would reimburse the processing plant. This program would create an incentive to collect and recycle. And for those that place plastics on the ground, there would be an employment opportunity for collection and recycling. A win-win for the environment and a financial incentive.

This video is awesome! I'd like to point out, though, that in addition to avoiding directly consuming plastic products, I think we all ought to consider more critically the plastic pollution inherent in the production of non-plastic products we consume.

Refusing plastic straws is great, but a 2018 study (1) showed that plastic straws only compose about .03% of the plastic in the GPGP. On the contrary, discarded fishing equipment accounts for 46% of that plastic. That means avoiding fish is 3 orders of magnitude more effective at preventing plastic pollution than avoiding plastic straws is. That is an incredible figure.

And even without all the plastic pollution, the fishing industry is incredibly unsustainable. Plastic kills millions of marine animals in a year (2), but millions of marine animal are killed for food each minute (3). That has a far more devastating impact on ecosystems than plastic does. Fish populations are declining at an alarming rate (4), and considering the ocean's role as one of our planet's best carbon sinks, that's a terrifying prospect.

If you want to engender positive change, cutting out fish, or better yet adopting a plant based diet, is the most effective method of making an individual sustainable impact.

I have to say that i like that video more than the other "against plastic" videos:
- Most of the other video are like: "No no, you are a bad customer because you buy plastic"
- Welp, there are whole industries that still producing plastic, either because they don't want to change or they can't change because there is no good alternative available which has the same physical properties plastics have. So before people should complain about plastic, they should also offer a better solution to replace it.
- and what also needs to be addressed is that what happens if i throw plastic in the correct bin: what comes afterwards. How is the waste industry handle it? Because i don't think it's just the "normal person" which throws plastic in the ocean

And we will just get that problem solved in the long run if people begin to research on alternatives and when they are there and they are equal to plastic, politics need to make sure financially that it's wiser to use the non-plastic alternative.

I also liked that the alternative bags are addressed in the video: They are not that "good shit" which everyone wants to tell you and their materials have their own downsides, in the production process and also in usage. For example cleaning them if something you bought is not completely sealed anymore, is a pain in the ass because the fabric structure holds on to "things". The Plastic Bag has a much smoother surface, water over it and it's gone. And for all that complaining about that example, think about this: Like with every product which is intended to be used for a very long time, maintenance is a factor. I say this because some people turn low-key into clerics if you "dare" to complain about the plastic alternatives.

Something to note : India and it's neighboring countries still do not have proper waste management systems. This means that all trash goes in the same bin, and is processed afterwards. This makes for a lot of problems, as sometimes plastic can go in the wrong area and end up somewhere else. And inaccessibility of trash cans is a major issue as well. Another problem is that when an area slowly starts to collect trash, people don't think "Hey, we should move this away", no. Instead, the idea becomes "Let's use this as our trash disposal area!". These types of activities overwhelm the already bad waste management system.

There is an easy solution to this problem, get a big metal chamber, shove a ton of plastic in it and put it under vacuum then heat it up (solar, nuclear, geothermal any heat works), this decomposes the complex long chain polymers down to short chain hydrocarbons like methane that can be used as 100% carbon neutral fuel or to make carbon-neutral plastics. And if you want to burn the plastic in open air you can reduce the effects of this by allowing the carbon dioxide to be passed through a solution of sodium hydroxide which reacts with CO2 to form sodium carbonate (and water) which can be used as a permanent medium for carbon sequestration, while the other byproducts of plastic combustion can be distilled out and saved for industrial applications.

One fact that is missing is that the plastic coming from Asia (and soon mostly Africa) is in fact the waste from companies and consumers from the US and other developed countries. We consume plastic products and then the “recycling” or waste gets sent to these countries to be processed for reuse. These processes are not well regulated and chemicals, and plastics end up in streams.

China wants to tackle this issue by not accepting developed countries waste and recycling, which means the US and others will be dealing with this problem shortly. I know this post is years after this video was posted, but the truth is people in the US, like myself, just keep consuming and tossing plastics in an effort to recycle, but there’s not a big market for recycled plastic and poor/undeveloped countries have no proper place for disposal nor do they have the space to properly dispose of the waste. People need to realize that plastic isn’t necessary for most things and should be used sparingly. Personally, I’ve decided to go low-waste, but here in America it’s difficult to be sure.

I mean. Plastic is now pretty deeply incorporated into the ecosystem. It causes extinction events and is extremely likely to be harmful to people in the long term. At the same time, it forces some pretty rapid adaptation. If the history of the entire world taught us anything, the species that don't die out will very likely evolve and simply use synthetic plastics (more accurately, synthetic monomers) as a part of their biochemistry in the long term.

Sure it will probably cause cancer (in a similar way asbestos does, micro or nano-plastics will disrupt cells). Yeah. But we're still overpopulating the Earth, and our life expectancy is way higher than it ever was. Not only that, but plastics are the greatest method of resource utilization since the invention of alloys and have actually enabled us to enter the Silicon age and literally make leaps in all scientific and medical fields.

Totally worth it. The fear of plastic is just a fear of the loss of agency. The average life expectancy will drop a decade (if nothing else changes), but who the hell cares? There are enough humans as it is, and we're working on ways to increase our life expectancy anyway. CRISPR is probably going to be a big thing used to resist carcinogens.

The fact about plastic bags vs cloth bags is a bit misleading. Sure you might have to use a cloth bag 7,000 times to make up for ONE plastic bag. But every time you use that cotton bag you are replacing another plastic bag. And then another and another. So if you go to the store once a week you’re replacing 52 plastic bags with that one cotton bag. So take the carbon emissions of 52 bags and compare it to 1 cotton bag. If you reused that plastic bag 7,000 times then yea I’ll believe it’s better for the environment than the cotton bag but you need to factor in the fact that a cotton bag is not the replacement for a single plastic bag. It’s a replacement for hundreds to thousands of bags. I think this misleading info is exactly why people don’t bother using reusable bags. I like the video and agree with most of it but that fact doesn’t seem like something you should have skimmed over because it makes people think that plastic bags are better for the environment

We would need to use our reusable bags 7,100 times before they would be less detrimental to the environment? First off, a few reusable bags shared in a household of people, which they all use for all of their lives, will easily be used that many times. That also means a lifetime of disposable plastic bags that are not thrown away multiple times a week. I know you were playing devils advocate with yourself with that comment, but that just shows how seriously weak of an argument there is to be made for continuing to use disposable bags, because that’s basically only a successful rationalization to not stop using disposable bags for people who aren’t the problem to begin with. Anyone who has a lifetime ahead of them, with a routine of using bags in their daily or weekly activities, or anyone who actually cares about not putting more plastic garbage out there for the sake of the other billions of people who are alive now or will be in the future, still have no excuse. It’s only if people won’t actually use that one reusable bag for as long as it holds up, in place of every disposable bag they would otherwise need, that it makes more sense to keep using plastic they have to toss out, and then that’s on them because they could use it even if the fact is that they won’t. It’s sad but the real truth is that our economy became dependent on certain things being sustainable before those things were actually determined to be sustainable, and now we’re all so snug in our comfort zones that we can’t step out of them long enough to fix what’s broken about them.

I am very disappointed that yet another presumably reputable source has quoted the Danish study, claiming that single use plastic bags have a smaller environmental footprint than cotton bags. The Danish study was flawed from the start as it had used a Canadian study to claim that single use plastic in the ocean did not significantly harm aquatic life...the Canadian study was about the impact of fishing gear on ocean animals, nothing to do with single use plastic products. When determining the environmental footprint of single use plastic products the author of the Danish study greatly over-estimated the environmental cost of manufacturing cotton bags by using outdated information. He also underestimated the environmental cost of plastic by neglecting to consider how much is and continues to be discarded in a most negligent and destructive way, and the cumulative impact on all life on earth.

For those of you who just found this video and are terrified, fear not! Here are a few things you can do to reduce your plastic use easily!
- replace plastic toothbrushes with ones made from bamboo
- buy food in bulk (as long as it isn't perishable)
- buy cleaning products that are designed to minimise plastic use (in the UK, you can shop from places like Iron and Velvet, Smol, or Ecover. Not sure about anything outside the UK but a Google search will let you know what's available in your area!)
- make your own lunches. Store it in reusable tubs. Also get a thermal mug with a lid. A little extra effort but it saves you moneh
- bring your own bags to your local greengrocers when buying fresh fruit and veg.

This is by far the best video on plastics.

The only subject missing is how most consumer plastics are infinitely recyclable. We can collect all of the oceans plastic pollution, and still be able to recycle and reuse over 90% of it. The only plastics that are not recyclable or reusable and cause more harm than good, are ironically... biodegradable plastics. It is also the most viable substitute for natural resources like metals and minerals; and by far the best use of crude oil possible.

Also, most consumer plastics are inherently inert, hypoallergenic, safe and even consumable like medicinal oral gel caps, beauty products, food binders, glycerin and food grade polyethylene glycol... it is some of unnecessary additives, like BPA, benzines, and colorants introduced during product manufacturing that are harmful.

Plastics in the Postal industry have contributed the most significant reductions to global deforestation. Plastics are also the single most contributing factor to the cost reduction, mass availability and shelf life extension of medications, availability and affordability of vehicles, computers and electronics to the world, revolutionized food and beverage preservation, and most importantly, the global distribution and delivery of clean water.

in my opinion, Additive Manufacturing could lead us to a way richer scenario for solution on this topic. Just by re-printing your current "plastic needs" (if you give me this joke lol) a good portion of the problem could be easly solved. With this new scope of manufacture scientists could re-think materials, what can lead to build new types of materials wich could be more eco-friendly (the scale of this kind of manufacturing helps around this subject) just such as people are doing with new eco-friendly homes made by giant 3D printers today, but of course, with increased vision around it. Along with renewable energy, a lot of changes are doable when thinking in a molecular scale, this whole scope of production is just too new, not to say big corporations are not intere$ted in real change, of course.

The problem is not really the possibilitys around technique in this topic, but mainly the fact our currently economic and social model do not fit with this needs, wich would have to be almost world-wide concerned and managed. This video is dangerously wrong on so many levels. Before scaring people, the maker's of this video need to educate themselves on the properties of a wide variety of plastic types and their ingredients. There was no attempt to distinguish between thermosetting and thermoplastic materials. Bakelite for example is NOT plastic.
Common packaging materials are PET, HDPE, PP, PLA, and rarely nowadays PVC. PLA is 100% made from corn and is totally recyclable. PET is also 100% recyclable via chemical polymerization. If incinerated, PET produces carbon dioxide and water.
PET does not contain BPA, that is only found in PC.
BPA is not used to improve transparency - wrong.
DEHP is not used in packaging materials. It is a plasticize to make flexible products such as raincoats, inflatable beds etc.
There are multiple errors on statistics.

When New York City instituted an ordinance requiring plastic-bag recycling (i.e. retailers like supermarkets needed to put out collection bins specifically for them), I decided to stop throwing out plastic bags just to see how many I went through...

...well, those things multiplied like rabbits . In order to conserve space till I could take them to a collection point, I developed a method of folding them down to about the size of an index card, stick them a dozen or so at a time under a heavy book till all the air was squeezed out, then stack them up in a flat-bottomed shopping bag for transport. When one of these bags filled to capacity (and assuming I didn't have anything better to do at the time), I'd take them to one of the local collection bin. Some trips I had anywhere from 700-1000+ to drop off To paraphrase a recent meme, "that's a lotta bags-age"

The thought of being skeptical about all environmental friendly products is not unreasonable, however we should consider how much of a difference even a small change can make. If you counted how many plastic bags you have used and threw away in your life so far, you will easily get to over 700 bags. In that case a cotton bag (if you replaced all or more than 700 plastic bag usage with it) would still be more environmental friendly.

In reality we cannot have a 0 percent carbon footprint. That is a misconception. The only thing we can do is choose the better of the evils. If production of a plastic bag is less harmful than a cotton bag then just reuse the plastic bag that you used last. Elongate its life. This is all a matter of calculation about what is better. Take into consideration that by using these bags you are still supporting these bags' production.

When nature first invented lignin (a polymer that forms an important component of wood), there was nothing alive that could decompose it. As a result, it accumulated in sediments and contributed to the vast coal deposits of the carboniferous. Eventually, so much carbon was buried in this manner that the climate cooled and the rainforest swamps covering much of the land collapsed. Eventually, microorganisms evolved which could digest lignin, and nature found a new balance.

Plastic is another such organic polymer. While my knowledge of organic chemistry is limited, I see no reason in principle why organisms couldn't digest it for food, just like fat, protein, or carbohydrate polymers, if they had the right enzymes available to do so. With the age of quantum computing approaching fast, it may soon be possible to design such enzymes from scratch, then print an appropriate DNA sequence to code for that enzyme and insert it into the genomes of certain bacteria or other organisms. These organisms could be released into the environment, where they would begin the task of decomposing plastics like any other organic material.

Indeed, once a decomposition enzyme is developed, it should be relatively easy to evolve enzymes that catalyze the reverse reaction - plastic synthesis. Within a few million years or less, I could easily see modern plastics becoming a natural part of Earth's ecosystems, with plants and animals using them for the same properties we use them for, and various decomposers breaking them down for food.

That is not to say we should ignore the problems caused by plastic pollution here and now. We should be careful, avoid using more than we have to, and we should especially look for ways to collect and dispose of it as cleanly as possible. In the long term, though, I expect plastics to be a positive development - a new material for nature's toolbox.

Plastic:
1) Durable
2) Plentiful
3) Versatile
4) Energy-Efficient
5) Recyclable

We’ve made absurd strides in science and engineering to make extensive use of those first 4 traits and somehow we’ve managed to make full, widespread use of the most important trait.

Now we approach the event horizon of pollution, along with the event horizons of other major ecological disasters.

It’s not too late, but we really need to pick up the pace.

Someone JUST turned me onto this channel :) I got my degree in Environmental Studies (BA) and have learned and cared about these issues for a long time. I’m not as tech savvy or pro as this guy but I DO intend to start sharing more on my channel....I’m into health, fitness, sustainability, and art mainly singing. Mermaid on the side....and that endeavor is dedicated to raising awareness for Ocean issues and conservation :) I’m far from perfect but I’m about this shit! I used to run a delivery juicing service here in the Bay Area, I bottled in glass mason jars and did jar recycling, and always had a mason jar on me, which let me skip a lot of coffee cups plastic and paper. Good conversation starter too bc people often asked me “what’s in the jar?” 😜 I never thought it made THAT big of a difference but when I don’t have a jar on me, im amazed by how the cups pile up. So even 1 small change CAN actually make a big difference especially if we multiply that effect by how many millions of us there are. As far as reusable wrapping goes.... there’s a cool new product/Co. I stumbled on called Etee - basically a waxed cotton fabric that is moldable, holds its shape and even water tight. Looks cool! Just make sure you look at things objectively and from multiple angles, and don't fall for the emotional face-value of a decision. Like explained in the video, for example, you might note that some alternatives to plastic have massive alternative environmental impacts, like tremendous water use or greenhouse gas emissions. My point being, don't abandon all plastic just to satisfy your moral impulse. Consider each major use of it independently. Water bottles (great for replacing with reusable non-plastic OR plastic alternatives) and most straws could go, whereas some other plastic products are better to use than alternatives but MUST be recycled responsibly to mitigate their impact.

Food for thought directed at comments advocating a plastic-free lifestyle.

Edit: Someone pointed out to me that we still don't have a good alternative to plastic straws for people with disabilities requiring temporary or permanent liquid diets. Paper straws dissolve and pose a choking hazard, and metal straws heat up too easily. Maybe silicone straws. Point being that you should look before you leap and advocate for straw bans.

Two factoids near the end of this video, to me, couldn't be stressed enough.
First, that the environmental influence of plastic is still less than known alternatives. As in, using a cotton bag, or paper bags, you do not necessarily reduce harm to the environment, and may actually increase it. When solving a problem, it's important that the cure isn't worse than the disease.
Second, that 90% of the plastic pollution is coming from China. That's not saying that the western world is without blame, but it does mean that if the entire western world went into the most pollution-preventing overdrive, it would still only have a minuscule impact on the whole problem. "Optimize at the bottleneck" is an obvious adage for software developers. Environmental activists need to adopt it as well.

It needs stating that 1.9km isn't a lot. I've walked much longer distances on foot. If that's the scale of all of our plastic, it shouldn't be difficult to find an empty 1.9kmx1.9km empty area, dig a 1.9km deep hole in it, and dump all of our plastic waste there. The only question is how to transport it.
So it's not separating and throwing your plastic in a different bin that'll make the difference. Rather, it's making sure that it ends up in properly sealed landfills, and not in sea or rivers.

I hope you all understand most of these comments are nonsensical. I've done injection molding, sheet, and film extrusion. My organs shifted when I read Plastic being exposed to heat causes cancer... (I'm curious how these people think plastic is formed into shapes or what treating the plastic does, Trust me folks bottles and keyboards don't grow on trees, nor do truckbed liners or trash bags) to banning all non recycled materials. I don't know if they mean all non repelleted plastics or just using straight regrind, which would make the extruders job much harder in cases based on thickness of the plastic and impurities but that's going to create so much waste it isn't funny. Plus if you're worried about microplastics you huff plastic dust all day from regrind. Which makes it more nonsensical that they cause harm. You'd see people working with plastic being as sick as coal miners, which you don't. Plastic degrades as it's reused Impurities rise exponentially every time plastic is reground. Plus when the colorant is IN the plastic it is IN the plastic. You can turn white to black but not black to anything else. Plus if the resin is different, something that would be impossible to track unless we had millions of different recycle bins for plastic color and resins (And every person was able to correctly identify the resin) None of these mix together and work for everything. You can have a blend but you need to know you're RUNNING a blend and what that blend is. So is your goal here to force so much big government into the plastic industry that we are forced to close all factories?

This problem will solve itself. As stated, polymers commonly exist in nature, but we love plastic is because nothing alive knows how use it for food. At one time millions of years ago, all the natural polymers were also at one time new, and nothing alive could eat those for a while either, such as cellulose. The planet likely was drowning in billions of tons of cellulose for centuries, before a mold or bacteria mutated and discovered a way to extract the energy in it, followed by a feeding frenzy explosion.

Once this does happen with plastic, it will stop being "the magic material that doesn't wear out". All plastic in our world will start to rot away, as these newly mutated molds and bacteria explode in population and spread across the planet. They will feast on all plastic everywhere, and our advanced civilization will fall to ruin. We will have only ourselves to blame for allowing this to happen, by not keeping our plastic waste under control.

Plastics are extremely valuable not by its price, but by its quality. The goal must to contain plastic within human society. In other words the infrastructure must so that no plastic ever ends up in environment. This includes sorting it out, recycling, new and less complex packaging (i call it 1 type of plastic per package and max of 2 types of non-binding materials in a package (plastic + alu or glass or carton or etc). Plus banning items we can live without - straws, small sticks that you find in candy, C/PP, glued packaging such as tetrapac, etc (actually a list needs to be made, because there is a lot of stuff we need to abandon and learn to live without). In the end of plastic and waste life we need modern recycling facilities and incinerators that produce electricity and/or heat. All in all - the goal is to construct a system that contains plastic within human society. Banning everything is not the answer. Plastics will never go away. We just need to make it cycle within our domain. Like used radioactive waste! We don't just through it in the forest, do we?.. Same here.

A good way to avert the conundrum of deciding whether or not recycling plastic is worth it is to re-use those one-use items that are usually thrown away so quickly. Even if you only re-use each item once, you effectively double its useful lifespan.

Examples:
I keep disposable plastic grocery bags that I get from stores to be later used as trash can liners.
I use the cable ties that come with many electronic devices for future cable storage and management.
I retain cardboard and paper boxes and packaging envelopes for storage or sending items later on.
When I have an item that breaks I always try my best to repair or salvage whatever I can from it before buying a new one.

There are many other examples too, many of which are even better for the environment (and your wallet) than recycling. Please upvote this so more people see it!

Another video of superb quality, one that’s picked up over 1.3 million views in just a day. Hopefully, millions more will find it, and take nine minutes to watch this beautifully constructed and animated collab all the way to the end.

Like the video explains, there isn’t one easy solution to the problems caused by the invention of plastic, and there are undoubtedly many very useful applications. But beyond calling our elected officials or lobbying our companies to effect change from top-down, we can also take individual action.

For example, my family and I try to recycle—not trash—every plastic product we use. We weren’t always consistent in doing so in the beginning, but after a while, it became second nature.

And when I go to public places that have separate disposal bins for trash, compost, and recyclables, and go to throw away plastics in the latter of the three, I often see items meant for the other two bins in the Recycle bin (and vice versa). When employees take these bins away, they usually won’t bother to move the stuff around to their correct places, and our environment suffers a result. That’s another area we can take two seconds out of our day to improve the world we all live and breathe in.

The greatest threat to our collective well-being isn’t malice, but apathy.

I'll tell you some solutions:

- Replace your plastic toothbrush with one that isn't made of plastic (like bamboo).

- Stop using disposable razors with plastic handles, stick to an electric razor that can be reused and recycled later on or use the SafeT razor. It has a metal handle and you can change out the blades when needed.

- Refuse plastic grocery bags, stick with reusable bags

- If you eat at a fast food or eat out in general, refuse the plastic lid and don't pick up a plastic straw, just sip from the cup or use a glass/metal straw

- Same goes for plastic forks, spoons and knifes, have a metal knife/fork/spoon handy (those camping knife sets)

- The media you consume, just go digital. All those blu-ray/dvd plastic cases will end up in the trash at some point...being a hoarder or someone who collects will have consequences. Imagine 1 billion people having the exact same library collection of Marvel/Disney ect movies. Basically 1 billion copies of the same fucking movies. Same goes for video games, go digital.

The only problem with these videos is that they portray these problems as "our" problems due to things that "we" decided to do. But nobody of the 99% worlds population ever decided to use plastic packaging that are fuckin 10 inch boxes for a 1 inch item in shops, none of us wanted that, nor did we decide to throw the plastic out in the ocean.
It's simply not correct, an oversimplification, to say that "we humans did this to ourselves". We didnt.
It's just as incorrect as the trope that human "nature" is to be violent tribal warmongers.
Also isnt true, the vast majority of the worlds population are civilians and have never in their entire lives killed anyone. Period.

The rich upper class factory / manufacturing CEO's and managers did this, they are the ones responsible for this global pollution, NOT the average man and woman on the streets. Yes, the average person USES plastic due to simply being required by life necessity to purchase water in plastic bottles (because there are no other kinds available in shops anymore) or buying a tiny USB stick surrounded by a fucking square meter of plastic packaging you need a chainsaw to open. Because there are no USB sticks just sold "openly" without stupid packaging.

Thats my point. "We" didnt choose to do it this way, the people in industrial power that focus on profit margins are the ones that did this, they are the ones that decided to save money by throwing shit into the ocean. We didnt.
I've never thrown a single plastic bag into the ocean. I throw it into the garbage bin.
What the government then does with it, is THEIR responsibility, we as citizens should be able to trust them to dispose of it in an ecological manner. Its not MY choice that every single product i buy is wrapped in a kilo of plastic, nor is it MY choice that it should all be thrown into the ocean.

Me, and the vast majority of the worlds population, are simply just trying to live our lives.
If they sold water in glass bottles, i'd still buy water (because i cant drink tap water here).
If they sold things wrapped in cardboard boxes instead of plastic boxes, i'd still buy those things.
I didnt ask for nor need plastic in that insane wasteful way. It's not "our" fault, it's the fault of the profit-obsessed elite.

Because this video have become so trending I think it's necessary to point out that the report allegedly made by the Danish government which concludes that it will take over 7000 uses to justify using a cotton bag over a plastic bag does so without taking almost any of the relevant factors into account.

The report itself has been subject to heavy criticism and for good reason. If you actually look into the report it concludes this point only on behalf of the co2 imprint it takes to produce the bags, instead of taking all sorts of other important factors into account such as the consequences of disposing the plastic vs a reusing cotton bag. And that means you can't get to this conclusion without bending the research so much that it actually fits this bold statement. It simply and probably wouldn't be true if the researchers actually had done a better research

I would like to encourage everyone and especially kurzgezagt to read the report and look into the criticism that's directed towards it. Because it's clear that while it's a flashy conclusion, it doesn't have any deep scientific evidence to support the claim that it would be better to use plastic bags in the long run vs using cotton bags.

*if you need a Danish translator in order to read the report or the added criticism, then feel free to contact me kurzgezagt

Work needs to be done in the area or pyrolysis. It’s basically heating the plastics up without oxygen to give us the starting material(oil). In theory, it’s possible to do that with the mixture of plastics found in waste streams, which is important because a big drawback of conventional recycling is that it’s difficult to sort the plastics. The yielded oil can be used as fuel or something to make more plastics from.

Overall tho, the world has a lot of problems to do with the environment, and I think that the long term solution to them is to think in terms of, what is possible with all the energy and technology in the world. You should technically be able to do anything with a high abundance of these two resources at your disposal. Replanting forests? GM trees. Food shortages? Vertical farms. Water shortages? Reverse Osmosis of seawater. CO2? Better batteries. All these technologies take time and people to develop. The people are only drawn in when there’s investment and money. Videos like this cut social barriers and touch everyone. Just imagine some senior cabinet member watching this before bed, the next day they mention it in a meeting, then there’s an ever so slight policy change that gets the country talking about it. Then there could be enough awareness to get this stuff the money and work it needs.

From an economics perspective, the solution is simple: institute a tax equivalent to the externality produced by plastics, and impose tariffs on plastic imports from any nations that refuse to do the same. The deadweight loss from overproduction is removed, the uses with the lowest marginal benefit cease while we retain the more beneficial uses, and we reach an economically and environmentally sustainable equilibrium.
Same with the cotton bag, tax it at it's externality. ($37/tonne of CO2e if you believe the Obama administration, $220/tonne if you believe Stanford researchers. + other factors).
Instead of having a handful of government funded researchers come up with the solution, by instituting a tax you can make this the top priority of every R&D lab in the country and you can get thousands of unique and competing solutions.

There is also the problem of waste storage and structure design. What's the use in collecting environmentally dangerous trash in open-air dumps where the next storm (standard cold-front is enough) would pick items off the top and drop them in a nearby area where they flow into the watershed? We need better ways of isolating this plastic from our trash and reusing them. Also, what's the point of perfecting recycling, trash collection, material use, etc. when we follow the latest building fads and construct our homes in a flimsy-twig fashion, resulting in hurricanes, tornadoes, floods, etc. destroying endless amounts of property? Our poor building-codes contribute to the trash problem, because every leveled (or damaged) house becomes trash. Until the rubble is properly cleaned-up, trash is going into the watershed!

We need to address the issues in this video, but I'd like to add that the scope isn't just what we "intend" to throw-out. The scope expands to unintended litter from poor accounting for natural occurrences. "Natural" disasters aren't nature doing something unusual, different-than-normal, unexpected, etc. "Natural" disasters are disasters because of our inability (or sometimes ignorance) to design structures to handle what nature does all the time! Earthquake, flooding, hurricane, and sometimes tornado damage are frequently avoidable. We need to refine our building codes (and research) to include fire (possible,) hurricanes and tornadoes, and other strong disasters.

Ok video, and we can all agree that plastic is a concern for the environment, but the claim that there is more plastic than fish in the ocean in 2050 has been disputed since there is a great uncertainty about the current amount fish and the prediction of plastic in the world in 2050. There has been several studies done to estimate the amount of fish, but it seem like the foundation who made the fish=plastic claim deliberately choose in the low end instead of the high end which is 28 times bigger. The plastic amount used by the foundation was based on a study that only predicted the amount in 2025 and the researchers behind the study said it wasn't possible to predict further. It smells like the foundation behind the claim want to drive a political agenda by inventing facts. I respect your channel a lot, but sad to see you push this "fact". It seems like scare tactics(maybe used with the best intentions).

It is a problem today because its been allowed to be. Unlike most things, plastics is self-regulated and/or poorly regulated. If only it was as clean and renewable as everything else we use, if only it was cheaper to grow and mine, if only it didnt rot like wood, corrode like iron, poison us like zinc and aluminum (and other commonly used metals/materials), if only it lasted longer/shorter...

Businesses decided long ago that plastic was a cheaper alternative than everything else that was used prior. It even created new directions for enterprising businesses and people, but the disposal of plastics is mostly at public expense, and that includes recycling old plastic in to new products.

The only real thing we need to do is find more uses for old plastics. Imagine if it could replace materials that are in short supply now eg sand as a building material, or even as a binder. What if the books in libraries were printed on old plastic rather than wood pulp? How about government forms and paperwork that decimates forests every year?

Why should i refuse single use plastic products when their reusable counterparts consume literally thousands of times more energy to produce and don't perform as well? Also, many people reuse "single use" plastic products. The "single use" plastic shopping bags make great trash bags for smaller bins, after they have been used to carrying purchased goods. They are also great for wrapping raw animal products. Many "single use" plastic bottles and jugs are great for storing and organizing dry goods such as grains, seeds, animal feeds, screws, bolts, etc.

As far as I know, they are made by extracting resins out of woods and then mixing wood-pulver back in, but there's probably other varietions too.
You can often find stuff made out of that in organic grocery stores and I'd like to know if they are actually better in sum.

On another note, here's some stuff I do:
Most "single-use" grocery plastic bags today are actually durable enough to be reused in a bunch of other ways.
I reuse them for shopping, travel, storage, crafting and carrying stuff around.
They are also really practical as trashbags: Instead of using single-use trashbags which really only have the use of landing in the trash, I can save up on those by reusing grocery bags, especially since these are way sturdier and save me from having to layer two trashbags for heavier trashloads.

There's also things like wodden toothbrushes which are pretty awesome.
Not sure if they are more eco friendly in production, but at least they degrade easier.
I also make sure to buy cleaning supplies by brands who make their packaging out of recycled plastic.

This really ignores a lot of the good that has come from plastics. For example the decrease in fuel use in transporting all of these products around the world. They are lighter (example - Plastic bottle v. Glass bottle) and more durable. People want their products to arrive without damage, everything gets wrapped in plastic. If it's not wrapped it gets damaged in transit and people complain or demand a refund which hampers business.

There does not appear to be an easy solution to this problem. Alternatives are out there like paper, bamboo, cork etc... but they do not possess the same properties. What we really need are solutions for renewable/sustainable packaging. Plastic is still awesome for all the good it does, just a shame people are so careless with disposing of it or recycling it.

Plastic bans are idiotic as they only address short term problems but do nothing to fix or solve the problem of transporting goods and reusing the packaging the goods come in. Most areas have recycling programs to address plastic use. It needs to be expanded to handle bags.

TLDR – watch: The Corporation (2003), Zeitgeist: Addendum (2008), Zeitgeist: Moving Forward (2011), The Choice is Ours (2016). I also recommend the following movies about the effects of capitalism: Earthlings (2005), Sicko (2007), Capitalism: A Love Story (2009) and The Cove (2009).

Plastic in and of itself is not a problem. The problem is capitalism because it's unsustainable. Capitalism is an economic system characterized by:
– lack of government intervention (government is controlled by corporations)
– means of production owned by private firms (who don't give a fuck about the rest)
– goods and services distributed according to price mechanism (wealth transfer)

In capitalism competition is temporary because small firms are cannibalized by big firms which get bigger and bigger and fewer and fewer. Competition ultimately gives rise to monopolies and monopsonies which don't compete with each other but actually cooperate because it's more profitable. This leads to low wages and scammed consumers.

Capitalism has boom and bust cycles, which is just another wealth transfer mechanism, another way to fuck people over and widen the abyss between the poor and the rich. Nothing makes the rich richer more spectacularly than a bust. This is leads to abject economic inequality. In capitalism it's more profitable to pollute then to not pollute, this is called negative externalities. A negative externality is a human, environmental or social cost of an economic activity that doesn't affect the parties who choose to incur them.

Capitalism depends on cyclical consumption. That's why capitalism invented planned obsolescence:
– the new phone doesn't fit the old charger
– the device is designed to break down just when the warranty expires
– it's cheaper to buy a new device than to fix the old one
– which means it's cheaper to throw things to the garbage than to fix them
– although the product works fine, you gotta get the new shit because advertising

Because all corporations are doing it, it's pointless to go to the "competition" when you're unsatisfied with the manufacturer of your product.

Another part of the problem is psychological.
I'm going to call it "the cleaners burden", what I'm talking about is, people have the ability the absorb burdens from other people and situations, and people also have the ability to dump their burdens onto others or into places.
Ask any person who works as a cleaner, they will confirm that the majority of people dump burdens.
For example, throwing some trash at a bin and missing, and then saying "I'm leaving it there because I don't want to deal with it"
A cleaner will find many examples of this burden dumping behavior. That's why I call it "the cleaners burden", because psychological burden dumping is most noticeable in cleaning work.
The solution to this part of the problem has to tackle the cause, not solely the symptoms, and tackling the cause to "psychological burden dumping" involves a massive change, specifically, getting everyone on the planet to discipline themselves 24 hours a day to observe and eliminate any dumping behavior, including any behavior that they don't even think about and yet affects others.
Just 1 single person abusing this system would create a ripple effect.
This under taking would also require every person to have the ability to check if everyone else was following the self discipline guidelines.
Also required is having the majority of people prove that they can respect boundaries, personal privacy to name one, respect of high priorities over low priorities is another, because if most people aren't respecting boundaries then you must assume that any change people make will only be temporary. It will be like a game of musical chairs where everyone follows rules until a point, and then everyone reverts back to taking advantage of the benefits as soon as the music stops, and if you're caught "without a chair" that's you're fault because you didn't vote for the respect of boundaries and priorities, disrespecting those things got voted in through everyone's acceptance of it, so that became the standard everyone was expected to uphold during their worst... if that's you at your worst, then someone else is gonna take the chair from you when the music stops because they know what you'll do.
You have to sacrifice a low priority for a high priority, even if it benefits someone else, otherwise you'll never be expected to behave well if and when the music ever stops.

There are many requirements to fixing the psychological burden dumping... self discipline, policing, changing expectations... all very massive, but all achievable.
They won't just achieve themselves though.

THE STORY OF MIDAS.
Once upon a time, there was a greedy king who had metals, diamonds, and riches. Of all the riches, he didn't have much gold. He REALLY wanted gold. One day, the king was out on a walk only to spot a drunk satyr (a goat-man hybrid) in a hole. Always drunk as in follower of Dionysus (Greek god of festivity, excitement, party, wine, ya know da deal.) Always drunk. So Midas is like "yo bruh. I be helping u get out of dis hole and u be living in LUXURY!!!" Then the satyr be like "yo bruuuuuhhh! Yeah! I totalllllllllllyyyyyy want OUT!!! Cool brrruuuuhhhh!" So Midas is takin' care of da satyr and da next day Dionysus comes to visit. (Yay?) So Dionysus thanks Midas and Dionysus is like "Yo bruh. Is cool how u helped Mr. Satyr here. I owe you one. How 'bout a wish?" Midas be like "YASSSSS!!!!!!!!! GOLD. NOW. please?" Dionysus be like "gold touch?" Midas be like "YASSSSS!!!!!!!!!! GOLD TOUCH!!!" Then the rampage of turning everything to gold happens... Midas be HUNGRAY!!!!!!! He takes a grape outta his new golden bowl and nearly shatters his teeth. (Ouch!) the grape had turned to gold. He decided to rest on his bed. Long story short, the bed turned to gold. He tried hugging his only daughter, but she turned to gold. Longer story short, he got rid of his powers by ...bathing in a river... You might've thought, "oh he learned his lesson, bla Bla BLA." BUT NOOOOOOOOOOOOO. OF COURSE HE HADN'T!!!!!!!!!! He was on ANOTHER walk. This time spotting a pan(Greek god of the wild) party. Pan was playing his "lair" and Midas drunk, said " pan be better musician than Apollo.( Greek god of the Sun, art, prophecies, hunt, bow, music, medicine, plague, and much MUCH more. You heard music, right?) so that got Our little friend Apollo triggered. Midas got ass's ears and his barber found out. He swore secrecy. One day the barber dug a hole in the Earth(Gaea) and said" Midas has ass's ears." And soon everyone found out. They remembered Midas not as a king, but as something else.
THE END.

I am a Land Surveyor and we have a contract with a few of the local landfills. The first time I went out there was incredibly eye opening and instantly forced me to pay close attention to both how I dispose of items and what items I buy in the first place. I think everyone should have to visit a landfill and see where their trash is going. One of the sites has a “mound” almost a mile long and 800ft wide that goes 100ft into the ground and 80ft above the ground. I first went out there last summer when they were finishing filling up one cell while laying the foundation for a new one. Upon my next visit, three months later, they already had 60ft of the new 800x600ft cell filled up. It’s terrifying.

I think the worst part is the amount of wildlife that is present at these sites. Deer, bear, many types of birds including bald eagles, seagulls, turkey buzzards, hawks. And, of course, plenty of rodents.

The landfill does what it can to contain all chemicals and runoff, but it is surely far from perfect. At the bottom is an abundance of black water that I was warned not to come in contact with in order to avoid chemical burns.

Be mindful of the effect you have on the world, we only have one and are nowhere near finding a backup planet.

You know... People, engineers and scientist have for a while come up different solutions, some passive, some active, to get plastic gathered from oceans. It is there waiting just to be picked up. But do you know why none of the "nuclear" solutions, like basically an floating oil rig kind of set-up that sails the oceans gathering plastic then processing it, have not seen the light of day? I would compare it to something that matters in the context, e.g., the estimated number of fish in the oceans, or their mass, or something where the comparison can be made. Without that, the bare numbers tend to overexaggerate the reality. I am not trying to say that the figures are insignificant, they are actually terrifying, however, context would help.

There are a couple big points that I don't think received adequate coverage in this video -- first, the problem of adsorption of heavy metals onto plastics, which creates a path for introduction of these metals (eg. mercury) into food chains. Second is the production of microplastic particles from clothing. By extruding plastic through tiny carefully engineered shaped orifices to produce "microfibers" we can make cloth that does amazing things, wicking moisture in channels or cleaning with sharp microscopic fiber edges. But these fibers break during use and laundering, and form a new input of plastic into the air and water. The fuzz you pull out of your dryer lint trap contains a lot of tiny bits of plastic now, and some of that ends up in the air. A lot of it goes into the water dumped from the washing machine as well.

This may be shortsighted of me, but couldn't the problem be helped by just putting giant nets at the end of these rivers? Just at the top where the plastics float so marine life can still get through. The plastics won't be broken down yet because it takes so little time to reach the end of a river.

Part of the reason the Chinese burn through so much plastic is that _Chinese people refuse to recycle_. They don't care enough. If you've been to any major Chinese city (like Shanghai or Beijing), you'll see that there are separate receptacles for recycling and rubbish. However, one look inside the recycling receptacle and you'll see all sorts of refuse, like food, soiled napkins, and disgusting brown slime that smells like a sewer. Probably because it's a very similar substance to sewer water.

When the cleaning crew comes along to empty the receptacles, the recycling and rubbish get poured back together. I would like to believe that this is because the recycling is too polluted to be actually useful and not because the city or the worker doesn't care.

Because of the carelessness, when a Chinese environmental group did a "rubbish dig" in Shenzhen, they found that after draining the brown sludge, there was only about 65%, by mass, of the material that was actually recyclable (e.g. cans and bottles). That's like mixing the rubbish in the cans at random then throwing in a half dozen cans and a beer bottle in the correct container.

China's recycling is unfit to be recycled.

Also, it's cheaper to make new plastic in China than recycle.

Hey, a Dane here. That study made by the Danish government has been called into question because the only parameter in regards to the environment it took into account was if all kinds of bags were incinerated upon discarding and affected the ozone layer as a result.  The issue with this conclusion is that the material of old cotton totes are often reused to make new totes or other products instead of being destroyed like a broken plastic bag would so its life cycle is not the same as that of a plastic bag. The real number of uses if one takes other environmental issues into account as well can be anywhere between 50 and 3,800 times, according to Henrik Beha Pedersen, environmental biologist, and Berit Asmussen, both from the organisation Plastic Change. Unfortunately the best source I have is an article called "Misinformation om plastikposer versus bomuldsnet" from the Danish publication Ingeniøren, so it is - you guessed it - in Danish.

In reality, plastic bags degrade into micro particles amazingly fast outdoors. The people pushing reusables usually don’t realize that production is not demand-driven because. It is a byproduct of oil production, which is why the price is so cheap. We have to find another use for the plastic for every grocery bag we don’t use for groceries. Reusable shopping bags are not the answer.

You know what I miss as a commonplace packaging material? Glass! It's made of sand, it degrades (via erosion) far faster than plastics, is less-reactive than plastics, it's frequently reusable... and when it's not, it's highly-recyclable. I appreciate that glasses aren't a suitable replacement for ALL packaging that uses plastics, but fluids (everything from ketchup to soft drinks to wiper fluid) could easily start being packaged in it. And many things currently packaged in plastic-lined steel or aluminium cans (like chopped tomatoes) could readily be sold in glass jars too. This, combined with a wordwide ban on microplastics and an effort to replace more and more soft plastics (such as those sometimes used to package fruits and vegetables) with bioplastics could go a long way to reducing plastic waste, but requires either immense coordinated consumer effort or, IMHO more-feasibly, legislation.
